Prerequisites: COMPLETION OF ALL LOWER DIVISION COURSEWORK
Course Description: FOCUSES ON THE INTERACTION BETWEEN THE FIELDS OF ACCOUNTING AND MANAGEMENT WITH EMPHASIS ON ANALYSIS OF ACCOUNTING RECORDS AS AN AID FOR MANAGERIAL DECISIONS.
Objectives / Learning Outcome(s) / Major:
UPON COMPLETION OF THIS COURSE, A STUDENT IS ABLE TO:
1.  DISTINGUISH BETWEEN JOB ORDER AND PROCESS COST SYSTEMS INCLUDING ADVANTAGES AND DISADVANTAGES OF EACH.
2.  IDENTIFY CHARACTERITICS OF FIXED AND VARIABLE COSTS AND THEIR RELATIONSHIP TO INCOME.
3.  UNDERSTAND THE BUDGET PROCESS AND PREPARE A BUDGET.
4.  CALCULATE MATERIAL AND LABOR VARIANCES FROM STANDARDS.
5.  UNDERSTAND RESPONSIBILITY ACCOUNTING FOR DECENTRALIZED OPERATIONS.
6.  PREPARE DIFFERENTIAL ANALYSIS REPORTS
7.  HAVE A BASIC UNDERSTANDING OF ACTIVITY-BASED COSTING
8.  UNDERSTAND THE CONCEPT OF A JUST-IN-TIME ENVIRONMENT.
9.  UNDERSTAND THE BASICS OF CAPITAL INVESTMENT ANALYSIS
10.  IMPROVE BOTH ORAL AND WRITTEN COMMUNICATION SKILLS
11.  INTRODUCE PRINCIPLES OF ETHICAL AND PROFESSIONAL BUSINESS CONDUCT
Textbook(s): ACCOUNTING PRINCIPLES, 21ST EDITION--BUNDLE PACKAGE PRACTICE SETS---DYNAMIC DESIGN AND PA CONTAINERS, WORKBOOK AND SOFTWARE
Transfer Status: GUARANTEED TRANSFER TO INSTITUTION OFFERING SAME COURSE.
